You know Jamshedpur as India‚Äôs first planned industrial city. But do you know how the city got its name?‚Äã ‚Äã Decades ago, Jamsetji Tata was looking for a suitable land to set up an iron and steel industry ‚Äì the first ever in India. This endeavour began to take shape in the early 1900s, after a meeting with renowned geologist and metallurgist Charles Page Perin. A land was identified; this land was a small village called Sakchi.‚Äã ‚Äã Under the leadership of Sir Dorabji Tata construction began in 1908, and by 1912 the first ingot rolled out of India‚Äôs first steel plant. In the unassuming village of Sakchi, Tata Steel was born and India got its first integrated steel manufacturer!‚Äã ‚Äã Years later, #TDTY in 1919, Lord Chelmsford, the then Viceroy of India, renamed Sakchi to Jamshedpur after Jamsetji Tata as a gratitude to the company. #ThisIsTata

With a vision for a circular economy, this pilot project, aligned with the Government‚Äôs Swachh Bharat Mission, has commenced in 36 stores of Reliance Retail including Smart Bazaar and Sahakari Bhandar stores in Mumbai and Delhi, and will expand to 200 stores across the country by 2025 with a target of collecting 5,00,000 PET bottles annually in the pilot phase. The initiative was launched in the presence of Kazi Irfan, Officer on Special Duty (OSD), Solid Waste Management, Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC), at Reliance Retail‚Äôs Smart Bazaar store in Santa Cruz. The installed RVMs and collection bins will give consumers a convenient way to deposit used PET bottles in exchange for compelling discounts on Coca-Cola India products. The disposed PET bottles will be collected and recycled by Reliance Industries (RIL), a leader in the recycling of polyester and plastics. This initiative will facilitate smooth waste collection by engaging consumers in responsible waste management - transitioning away from a traditional linear economy. cocacola_india

Reliance Industries Becomes First in India to Use Chemical Recycling for Circular Polymers The new innovation is a testimony to the company‚Äôs commitment in reducing plastic waste and supporting Circular Economy in India Reliance Industries Limited (RIL), operator of the world's largest integrated refining and petrochemical complex, has become the first Indian company to chemically recycle plastic waste-based pyrolysis oil into International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC)-Plus certified Circular Polymers. This new innovation is a testimony to RIL's commitment in reducing plastic waste and supporting Circular Economy in India. RIL shipped its first batch of ISCC-Plus certified Circular Polymers, named CircuRepol‚Ñ¢ (Polypropylene) and CircuRelene‚Ñ¢ (Polyethylene). RIL paves the way in India by using new technology to recycle plastic by converting plastic waste into special Circular Polymers, thereby making a positive impact on the environment. RIL‚Äôs commitment to sustainability is demonstrated through its innovative methods like chemical recycling which help create a Circular Economy. The company firmly believes in finding smart solutions to reduce plastic waste and inspire others to join in this journey towards a greener future. CircuRepol‚Ñ¢ and CircuRelene‚Ñ¢ have been designed to lead the way in Circular Economy practices. RIL's Jamnagar refinery became the first refinery to get the important ISCC-Plus certification, proving that it can produce Circular Polymers through chemical recycling. The ISCC-Plus certification guarantees that traceability and rules are followed in making Circular Polymers. RIL has developed a technology that turns different types of plastic waste, including single use and multi-layered plastics, into pyrolysis oil. The company is working with trusted partners to increase the production of this oil and turn the yield into Circular Polymers. Chemical recycling has many benefits, including turning plastic waste into high-quality materials for new plastic. These materials can be used for packaging that comes into contact with food. #WeCare #RelianceInnovation #CircularEconomy #SustainableFuture

Jio and TM Forum open first Innovation Hub in Mumbai with Gen AI, LLM and ODA projects underway to accelerate industry growth Mumbai, December 1, 2023: TM Forum, the leading global alliance of telco and tech companies and Jio, a subsidiary of Reliance Industries Limited, today held the opening ceremony for the first TM Forum Innovation Hub, located in Mumbai, India. The Innovation Hub, the first of its kind for the industry, will focus its first efforts on accelerating the development of Generative AI (Gen AI) and Large Language Models (LLM) and Open Digital Architecture to benefit the whole industry. One of the hub‚Äôs first focus areas is the application of Generative AI and LLM to priority use cases for telcos, including developing an architecture blueprint to simplify responsible use of generative AI for brownfield telecoms technology landscapes, including the related challenges of security, privacy, accuracy, performance and scalability. A second focus area will focus on accelerating the development and adoption of TM Forum‚Äôs Open Digital Architecture. ODA underpins the creation of modular, componentized, and reusable cloud-native software to replace traditional BSS and OSS. Objectives include creating Reference Implementation(s) of the ODA Canvasand components, as well as migration patterns and innovative approaches to simplify migration from legacy software to ODA-compliant, cloud-native components.

A publication, ‚ÄòFostering Resilience for Sustainability: Reliance Foundation's Millet Experiences‚Äô, that documents learnings from millet interventions in different states was released on the occasion. Since 2010, Reliance Foundation has been focusing on sustainable agriculture and strengthening of food systems through a collaborative approach with various stakeholders. You know Jamshedpur as India‚Äôs first planned industrial city. But do you know how the city got its name?‚Äã Decades ago, Jamsetji Tata was looking for a suitable land to set up an iron and steel industry ‚Äì the first ever in India. This endeavour began to take shape in the early 1900s, after a meeting with renowned geologist and metallurgist Charles Page Perin. A land was identified; this land was a small village called Sakchi.‚Äã Under the leadership of Sir Dorabji Tata construction began in 1908, and by 1912 the first ingot rolled out of India‚Äôs first steel plant. In the unassuming village of Sakchi, Tata Steel was born and India got its first integrated steel manufacturer!‚Äã Years later, #TDTY in 1919, Lord Chelmsford, the then Viceroy of India, renamed Sakchi to Jamshedpur after Jamsetji Tata as a gratitude to the company. #ThisIsTata

Media Release - Coca-Cola India and Reliance Retail Team Up for ‚ÄúBhool Na Jana, Plastic Bottle Lautana‚Äù PET Collection and Recycling Initiative ¬∑ Pilot initiative commenced in 36 Reliance Retail stores in Mumbai and Delhi ¬∑ PET collection and recycling initiative to be expanded to 200 Reliance stores in India by 2025 ¬∑ Aims to collect 5,00,000 PET bottles annually in the pilot phase Mumbai, 15th January 2024: Coca-Cola India and India‚Äôs largest retailer, Reliance Retail announced the launch of a sustainability initiative titled ‚ÄúBhool Na Jana, Plastic Bottle Lautana‚Äù, focused on post-consumer PET collection at Reliance Retail stores in Mumbai through Reverse Vending Machines (RVMs) and collection bins. With a vision for a circular economy, this pilot project, aligned with the Government‚Äôs Swachh Bharat Mission, has commenced in 36 stores of Reliance Retail including Smart Bazaar and Sahakari Bhandar stores in Mumbai and Delhi, and will expand to 200 stores across the country by 2025 with a target of collecting 5,00,000 PET bottles annually in the pilot phase. The initiative was launched in the presence of Kazi Irfan, Officer on Special Duty (OSD), Solid Waste Management, Brihanmumbai Municipal Corporation (BMC), at Reliance Retail‚Äôs Smart Bazaar store in Santa Cruz. The installed RVMs and collection bins will give consumers a convenient way to deposit used PET bottles in exchange for compelling discounts on Coca-Cola India products. The disposed PET bottles will be collected and recycled by Reliance Industries (RIL), a leader in the recycling of polyester and plastics. This initiative will facilitate smooth waste collection by engaging consumers in responsible waste management - transitioning away from a traditional linear economy. Speaking on the launch, Mr. Damodar Mall, Chief Executive Officer, Grocery Retail, Reliance Retail Limited, said, ‚ÄúIndian families have had the habit of not trashing milk pouches, plastic bottles, even newspapers, daily. We clean, collect them, and hand them over to raddiwalas, who in today‚Äôs world are the unique front-end army of recyclers. SmartBazaar, as a modern retailer continues to encourage this habit, with modern methods. Our pilot with our store shoppers, with the support of Coca-Cola India and Reliance Industries, is one such attempt we plan to pursue with our wide network of stores.‚Äù Ms. Greishma Singh, Vice President ‚Äì Customer and Commercial Leadership, Coca‚ÄëCola India and Southwest Asia, said, ‚ÄúThrough this partnership and platform, we are delighted that we can generate awareness and provide shoppers a convenient way to recycle their PET bottles while they are shopping at their Reliance store. Partnerships with retail, government, civic societies, and consumer-centric ideas like this one are a powerful multiplier for progress on collection, recycling, and reuse.‚Äù Mr. Hemant D Sharma, President - Growth and Strategy, Polyester, Reliance Industries Limited, said, ‚ÄúReliance stands as a trailblazer in sustainability and circularity, leading India's charge in transforming waste into valuable resources. Recycling 2 billion PET bottles annually, with a plan to scale it to 5 billion, RIL epitomizes a commitment to sustainability that predates current trends and sets the standard for eco-friendly manufacturing. For over two decades, RIL has championed recycling post-consumer PET bottles, demonstrating a foresighted dedication to a greener, circular future.‚Äù This initiative is a key step toward Coca-Cola‚Äôs commitment to collect and recycle the equivalent of 100% of the packaging the company produces as part of its World Without Waste strategy. It will act as an anchor, retaining the sustainability momentum activated by Coca-Cola India‚Äôs 'Return and Recycle' initiative in collaboration with Zepto which has witnessed participation from 50,000 households in India and the successful RVM installations across 75 cities in the country, collecting 1 Tonne of PET waste. About Coca-Cola India: Coca-Cola in India is one of the country‚Äôs leading beverage companies, offering a range of high-quality and refreshing beverage options to consumers. The company in line with its vision of ‚ÄòBeverages For Life‚Äô offers a wide portfolio of products which includes hydration, sports, sparkling, coffee, tea, nutrition, juice and dairy based products. In India its beverage range includes Coca-Cola, Coca-Cola Zero Sugar, Diet Coke, Thums Up, Charged by Thums Up, Fanta, Limca, Sprite, Maaza, Minute Maid range of juices. The Company also offers hydration beverages including Limca Sportz, Smartwater, Kinley, Dasani and Bonaqua packaged drinking water and Kinley Club Soda. Premium products constitute Schweppes and Smartwater. In addition, it offers Costa Coffee- a range of tea and coffee. The Company is constantly transforming its portfolio, from reducing sugar in its drinks to bringing innovative new products to market. The Company along with its owned bottling operations and franchise bottling partners has a strong network of close to 4 million retail outlets through which it refreshes millions of consumers across the country. It seeks to positively impact people‚Äôs lives, communities and the planet through water replenishment, packaging recycling, sustainable agriculture initiatives and carbon emission reductions across its value chain. Globally together with its bottling partners, The Coca-Cola Company employs more than 7,00,000 people, helping to bring economic opportunity to local communities worldwide. message: Media Release - Jio and TM Forum open first Innovation Hub in Mumbai with Gen AI, LLM and ODA projects underway to accelerate industry growth Mumbai, December 1, 2023: TM Forum, the leading global alliance of telco and tech companies and Jio, a subsidiary of Reliance Industries Limited, today held the opening ceremony for the first TM Forum Innovation Hub, located in Mumbai, India. The Innovation Hub, the first of its kind for the industry, will focus its first efforts on accelerating the development of Generative AI (Gen AI) and Large Language Models (LLM) and Open Digital Architecture to benefit the whole industry. Leaders from both organizations and representatives from the Innovation Hub Founding Members including Accenture, Deutsche Telekom, Google Cloud, Orange, Telenor and Vodafone attended the ceremony at the Reliance Corporate IT Park in Navi, Mumbai, where hybrid teams made up of talent from across the telecom and tech industry will collaborate to deliver breakthrough thinking and solutions for the industry‚Äôs most pressing challenges. Mumbai was selected as the location for the first TM Forum Innovation Hub in recognition of India being the epicenter of global software development talent. Its opening builds on the TM Forum‚Äôs long-standing commitment to India ‚Äì where more than 37,000 active Forum member professionals are based. One of the hub‚Äôs first focus areas is the application of Generative AI and LLM to priority use cases for telcos, including developing an architecture blueprint to simplify responsible use of generative AI for brownfield telecoms technology landscapes, including the related challenges of security, privacy, accuracy, performance and scalability. A second focus area will focus on accelerating the development and adoption of TM Forum‚Äôs Open Digital Architecture. ODA underpins the creation of modular, componentized, and reusable cloud-native software to replace traditional BSS and OSS. Objectives include creating Reference Implementation(s) of the ODA Canvasand components, as well as migration patterns and innovative approaches to simplify migration from legacy software to ODA-compliant, cloud-native components. Commenting on the opening of the Innovation Hub: Mr Akash Ambani, Chairman, Reliance Jio Infocomm Limited: ‚ÄúThe TM Forum Innovation Hub is about delivering real-world solutions that will change our industry and there is no better way than to lean on talent from across the industry to solve our existing challenges as well as finding better ways to overcome future obstacles. We are delighted to see the first innovation hub open on our Mumbai campusas I believe Mumbai is the perfect location to foster the innovation needed. This is a really exciting time for Jio, TM Forum and the wider telecoms industry and we are honoured to be at the heart of this project.‚Äù Dr. Steffen Roehn, TM Forum Chair and Partner at Bain & Company: ‚ÄúRapid, open collaboration is today more important for our industry‚Äôs future than ever before. The TM Forum Innovation Hub will prove hugely beneficial as our members explore new technologies, more radical approaches to transform their organizations and strengthen their muscles. We‚Äôre delighted to be collaborating closely with Jio and all the founding members on this first Innovation Hub in Mumbai and look forward to seeing the first outcomes from the hub‚Äôs pilot projects.‚Äù Nik Willetts, CEO, TM Forum: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm thrilled to see work begin at the first ever TM Forum Innovation Hub here in Navi Mumbai. Our vision is to bring together our industry‚Äôs best talent in a neutral, entrepreneurial environment to rapidly deliver breakthrough thinking and answers to the industry‚Äôs most pressing challenges. The first projects reflect two of the most important areas for rapid innovation: the responsible and effective use of generative AI, and accelerating the pathways to an Open Digital Architecture to drive growth. Our sincere thanks to all of our Innovation Hub founding members ‚Äì and in particular Jio, who have given our first Hub a home.‚Äù The Innovation Hub program was unveiled two months ago at the TM Forum‚Äôs annual DTW ‚Äì Ignite conference in Copenhagen. Founding members Accenture, Deutsche Telekom, Google Cloud, Orange, Reliance Jio, Telenor and Vodafone are all contributing a range of expertise and resources to the hub, including experts, physical space, technology capabilities and professional services. The first Innovation Hub teams will be made up of staff from these organizations working both physically and virtually. The outcomes of Innovation Hub projects will benefit the entire TM Forum membership, and the wider industry in several ways: ¬∑ Providing a new way for the industry to collaborate at speed, solving intractable industry challenges with ‚Äòreal‚Äô results that can be practically implemented ‚Äì including working code or concepts proven at scale in operational or shadow-operational environments ¬∑ Testing and iterating TM Forum standards, providing valuable implementation experience to core standards development teams ¬∑ Accelerating the development of code assets (for example, Open Digital Architecture components and Open APIs) to be contributed towards TM Forum collaboration projects ¬∑ Industrializing concepts explored in the Catalyst program, sharing the learnings with the broader industry The pilot phase of the Innovation Hub program is expected to conclude in March 2024, with a third pilot project starting shortly. TM Forum Members will be invited to apply to join an existing Innovation Hub project or propose a new one in 2024. To be considered to join a project Member companies will need to bring the distinct expertise the project requires, as well as meet the minimum dedicated resource commitment. To keep updated on the work of the Innovation Hub program and its first cohort of companies, visit https://www.tmforum.org/tmf-innovation-hub/. About TM Forum TM Forum is a global alliance of telco and tech companies, leading the industry in defining the building blocks for new operating models, impactful new partnerships, and advanced software platforms. TM Forum helps its members unlock the value of data to create nearly endless opportunities for players across the communications ecosystem. At DTW Ignite, Accelerate and Collaboration events, TM Forum provides a platform for industry change-makers to share groundbreaking innovation, market developments, product launches and business transformation journeys. We are the only industry body to count the world‚Äôs top 10 CSPs and all the key hyperscalers as active, strategic members. With over 800 members, we are on a mission to reinvent the telco industry as a vibrant part of the digital landscape ‚Äì and a driving force in shaping its future. It is the only network conceived as a Mobile Video Network from the ground up. It is future-ready and can be easily upgraded to support even more data, as technologies advance to 6G and beyond. Jio has brought transformational changes in the Indian digital services space to enable the vision of Digital India for 1.4 billion Indians and propel India into global leadership in the digital economy. It has created an eco-system comprising of network, devices, applications and content, service experience, and affordable tariffs for everyone to live the Jio Digital Life. It has been a busy year at Reliance Retail, as India‚Äôs most loved and largest retailer, discovered new ways to reach and serve its customers and grow the businesses of its partners including micro, small and medium enterprises, kiranas, artisans, and craftspersons. One of the ways of addressing the needs of customers is to offer a wider assortment, whether its daily-need or difficult-to-find items. Reliance Consumer Products Limited (RCPL), the FMCG arm of Reliance Retail, kicked off the year by doing just that. In January, it strengthened its beverage portfolio by acquiring a 50% stake in the century old Sosyo Hajoori Beverages and followed it up by bringing Sri Lanka‚Äôs Maliban biscuits to India with the aim of developing new value propositions for the domestic market. Being the official retailer of GAP in India, Reliance Retail in February opened the apparel brand‚Äôs first freestanding store in Mumbai having already launched over 50 shop-in-shops. The next month, however, it was RCPL, which stirred up the domestic beverage market by launching the iconic Campa. By April, things started heating up. Being the country‚Äôs most preferred retailer is by no means an easy task with Indian customers expecting Reliance Retail to offer value and variety in other areas apart from daily essentials and apparel. In stepped Tira, Reliance Retail‚Äôs beauty platform, which apart from launching freestanding stores, reached customers across 100 pin codes through its app. Later that month, Reliance Brands amped up the buzz further by bringing one of UK‚Äôs best-known food chains, Pret A Manger to India. After four months of acquisitions and launches, May promised to be quiet. The team at Reliance Retail, however, had other plans. It completed the Rs 2,850 crore acquisition of German retailer, Metro‚Äôs wholesale business in India with the aim to not only boost its business-to-business (B2B) but help modernize more kirana partners. RCPL, too, jumped on the bandwagon. It purchased 51% stake in Lotus Chocolates, entered the western snacks category by partnering with General Mills to launch Alan‚Äôs Bugles chips in India and in June, took its Independence brand to North India. July witnessed Reliance Brands partnering with FDCI for Hyundai India Couture Week, while in August, one of world‚Äôs top investors, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) showed its faith in India‚Äôs retail growth story by investing $1 billion in Reliance Retail Ventures (RRVL) for around 1% stake, nearly doubling the company‚Äôs valuation to $100 billion from its last funding in 2020. In the same month, Reliance Retail launched its youth focused apparel and accessories brand, Yousta. By September, top private equity firm, KKR & Co Inc added to its bet on the country‚Äôs largest retailer by investing an additional $250 million. Subsequently, Reliance Retail picked up 51% stake in Bollywood star, Alia Bhatt‚Äôs kidswear and maternity wear brand, Ed-a-Mamma, while Reliance Retail-owned global toy brand, Hamley‚Äôs opened its first store in the world‚Äôs fashion capital, Milan. Moving into the festive season, October had much to cheer about with Reliance Retail buying the majority rights of UK‚Äôs Superdry IP for the Indian territory. The move was quickly followed by Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) investing $598 million in RRVL, valuing it among the top four companies by equity value in India. And to top it all, in what came as good news to thousands of Indian luxury shoppers, Jio World Plaza opened its doors Mumbai. And with the year drawing to a close, AJIO, Reliance Retail‚Äôs fashion e-tailer, in November introduced Ajiogram, India‚Äôs first ever direct-to-consumer (D2C) focused content-driven interactive e-commerce platform to empower startups in the fashion and accessories space. Similarly, Indian artisans and craftspersons had much to cheer about as the company launched the first Swadesh store in Hyderabad with the brand aiming to promote authentic handcrafted products and rich art forms in India and globally. And to carry on the festivities into the new year, the company bagged global beauty chain, Sephora‚Äôs India rights, too. The move is expected to not only bolster the company‚Äôs existing beauty business but offer more options to the burgeoning number of Indian beauty enthusiasts. #RelianceRetail #Rewind2023 #WeCare #RIL

message: 2023: RIL‚Äôs Year of Transition 2023 turned out to be a year of transition for Reliance Industries, which is India‚Äôs leading corporate in terms of revenues, profits, exports, market value, capital expenditure, employment generation, contribution to the exchequer, as well as social responsibility spending, and impact. Reliance‚Äôs transition towards Net Zero gained momentum, it became India‚Äôs largest bio-energy firm, it set up a world-class financial services firm, it scaled up gas output to 30% of India‚Äôs production, and also witnessed the next-generation leaders joining the Board of Directors. ‚Ä¢ Through 2023, all three large platforms of Reliance ‚Äì energy and materials, organised retail, and digital services ‚Äì made rapid progress on all the financial and operational parameters reaching new records. Reliance is also focused on the timely execution of its new renewable energy platform. ‚Ä¢ A New Reliance is now emerging as a new-age technology company with distinctive capabilities ‚Äì a net producer of technology, a large-scale deployer of technology, as well as a democratiser of technology. ‚Ä¢ Reliance‚Äôs ceaseless spirit of innovation is aimed at offering products and services of the highest quality at prices among the lowest in the world to enhance the quality of life as well as the ease of living of hundreds of millions of Indians. ‚Ä¢ Reliance marked the milestone of having cumulatively invested more than $150 billion (over Rs 12 lakh crore) in the last 10 years ‚Äî higher than any other corporate in India. ‚Ä¢ Reliance set up Jio Financial Services to accelerate the replication of India‚Äôs dazzling growth story in Bharat, by significantly increasing financial services penetration for each and every Indian with a digital-first approach and minimal cost of service. ‚Ä¢ JFS announced a JV with the world‚Äôs largest asset management company BlackRock to set up an asset management business to provide simple and trustworthy investment solutions in India. ‚Ä¢ Reliance‚Äôs Digital Services business under Jio unleashed the fastest rollout of 5G technology witnessed anywhere in the world, launched the Jio Bharat phone to make India 2G-mukt, launched JioAirFiber and demonstrated JioSpaceFiber to connect unconnected regions. Jio‚Äôs data traffic continued to rise in double-digits to cross 12 exabytes per month. ‚Ä¢ Reliance Retail achieved a $100 billion valuation milestone in three fundraising deals, in which marquee global investment firms QIA, ADIA, and KKR participated. RRVL is developing into a world-class institution, driving the transformation of the Indian retail sector and creating value for millions of customers and partners. ‚Ä¢ During 2023, Reliance revived natural gas production in KG-D6 block to 30MMSCMD, meeting ~30% of India‚Äôs production. After commissioning the R-Cluster and Satellite-Cluster projects in the last couple of years, this year Reliance commissioned the MJ Field ‚Äì one of the most complex and cost-efficient deep-water projects of this scale. ‚Ä¢ Reliance‚Äôs journey to transition its legacy O2C business into a sustainable and green, circular, and consumer integrated, chemicals and materials business gained momentum in 2023. o As the first leg of the transition, Reliance is creating the New Energy ecosystem of manufacturing Solar, Wind, Batteries, Hydrogen, and Bio-energy platforms o Secondly, Reliance is accelerating circularity and consumer integration, to deliver application-specific green products o Thirdly, with technology and innovation, it is turning the refinery at Jamnagar into a ‚ÄòChemicals and Materials Feedstock Production‚Äô engine. RIL started by converting some low-value refinery streams to recently launched highly specialised Halo-Butyl Rubber grades. ‚Ä¢ Reliance progressed with India‚Äôs first and world-class Carbon Fibre facility in Hazira, Gujarat, which will include carbon fibre and carbon fibre reinforced plastics, with an aim to be among the top three players globally. ‚Ä¢ Reliance remains focused on the fast-track execution of Dhirubhai Ambani Green Energy Giga Manufacturing Complex at Jamnagar, which will host one of the largest, most technologically advanced, flexible, and most cost-competitive Solar giga factory globally, converting sand into Solar PV modules. Reliance has set eyes on a target to accelerate and enable the installation of at least 100 GW of renewable energy generation by 2030. ‚Ä¢ Reliance is setting up its Battery giga factory by 2026, which will manufacture battery chemicals, cells, and packs, leading all the way up to containerised energy storage solutions, and will include a Battery Recycling facility to deliver a truly integrated ecosystem. ‚Ä¢ The year 2023 also marked RIL‚Äôs emergence as India‚Äôs largest Bio-energy producer based on its indigenously developed technology. Reliance commissioned the commercial-scale Compressed Biogas (CBG) plant at Barabanki in Uttar Pradesh, in addition to two demo units at Jamnagar. Reliance aims to establish 100 CBG plants in the next 5 years, consuming 5.5 million tonnes of agro-residue and organic waste, thereby mitigating nearly 2 million tonnes of carbon emissions. ‚Ä¢ Reliance‚Äôs Media & Entertainment business created a huge disruption last year, with JioCinema leading the way. More than 12 crore people watched the IPL final online making it the most-watched digital event globally and marking a tectonic shift in the way content is consumed in India. ‚Ä¢ The year 2023 also marked a transition in RIL‚Äôs leadership. Isha Ambani, Akash Ambani, and Anant Ambani joined the company‚Äôs Board of Directors and are set to work as one single team to provide leadership to the Reliance Group as a whole and with a holistic vision. ‚Ä¢ Bringing the best of the world to India as well as providing a world-class platform to showcase India‚Äôs prowess, craftsmanship, art and culture is one of the unique initiatives of Reliance. Furthering this aim, Reliance commissioned the Nita Mukesh Ambani Cultural Centre, and the Jio World Plaza in Mumbai in 2023. Together with the Jio World Convention Centre, the Jio World Garden and Jio World Drive, they have created an all-encompassing destination for the Indians to experience the world‚Äôs best brands and performances. ‚Ä¢ Under the leadership of Smt Nita Ambani, Reliance Foundation continued to work tirelessly to make lives better for millions of Indians. Through its multifarious activities, Reliance Foundation has so far touched the lives of nearly 70 million Indians across 54,000 villages across all states. Facilitating the children‚Äôs activities and volunteering at the venue, was Ms Isha Ambani who joined Reliance employee volunteers in cheering the children through the fun-filled events of the day that culminated with a storytelling session. The event with children marks over 75 days of Reliance Foundation‚Äôs ‚ÄòWe Care, We Volunteer - Kahani Kala Khushi‚Äô, campaign where over 1,200 Reliance employees volunteered have engaged 16,000 underprivileged children from across 25 cities of India through storytelling and art. ‚ÄúThe festive season is synonymous for all of us with spreading cheer among children. The excitement we saw among children across the country and here today was so infectious that it spurs us to continue this spirit of volunteering and inspire them to learn more, read more in an enjoyable atmosphere,‚Äù said Ms Isha Ambani. Reliance Foundation has been dedicatedly spreading joy among children from disadvantaged communities around this time of the year for over a decade now. This year, ‚ÄòWe Care, We Volunteer ‚Äì Kahani Kala Khushi‚Äô has been an intensive effort to combine storytelling, culture and art for the children that the Foundation supports through numerous organisations. It was held in 25 cities, including Ahmedabad, Bhubaneswar, Chennai, Delhi, Jaipur, Hyderabad and Mumbai. Volunteers engaged children by telling age-appropriate stories that helped them imaginatively discover India and creatively express their ideas, through art, up on being motivated by these stories. The stories covered festivals, folk and tribal stories and the stories had origins in their states. As the campaign aims to sustain their interest in art, art kits and material along with story books were also provided to the children. The storytelling continued for children at Jio Presents Hamleys Wonderland on Thursday, and all the children indulged in fun-filled extravaganza with attractions including Ferris Wonder Eye, arcade games, carousel, WonderTheatre and much more. The ‚ÄòWe Care, We Volunteer‚Äô ‚Äì Kahani Kala Khushi campaign is a continuation of Reliance Foundation‚Äôs sustained Education and Sports for All (ESA) programme. Through ESA, Reliance Foundation has supported children‚Äôs aspirations through various education and sports initiatives in collaboration with NGOs as part of continued efforts to inspire children.

Build on International Year of Millets momentum for ‚Äòthe crop of the future‚Äô say millet stakeholders ‚Ä¢ Reliance Foundation organises conference on ‚ÄòShaping Perspectives on Practise and Policy for Millets in India‚Äô ‚Ä¢ Publication on ‚ÄòFostering Resilience for Sustainability: Reliance Foundation's Millet Experiences‚Äô, learnings from millet interventions released on the occasion Diverse stakeholders from across India‚Äôs millet landscape emphasized that challenges of food security, farm livelihoods and nutrition diversity can be resolved in a climate-resilient manner, by building on the momentum generated during the International Year of Millets (IYOM). They were sharing experiences at a multi-stakeholder conference ‚ÄòShaping Perspectives on Practise and Policy for Millets in India‚Äô, organised by Reliance Foundation here today. Policymakers, farmer representatives, development sector stakeholders, researchers and industry representatives echoed the need for greater collaboration, increased farmer-focused efforts, and deliberated successes and challenges from both practice and policy within India‚Äôs millet landscape. A publication, ‚ÄòFostering Resilience for Sustainability: Reliance Foundation's Millet Experiences‚Äô, that documents learnings from millet interventions in different states was released on the occasion. Fostering Resilience for Sustainability showcases end to end interventions that include making quality seed accessible to farmers, providing continued technical support, strengthening market linkages, empowering women‚Äôs agency and building awareness of millets. Speakers at the discussions included Raman Wadhwa, Director, NRLM; Dr Neelam Patel, Senior Advisor, NITI Aayog; Priyanka Singh, Chief of Rural Transformation, Reliance Foundation; Prof. Ruth DeFries, Columbia University; Prasoon Bhardwaj, Head of Staples, Reliance Retail; K P Kavitha, CEO, Kazhani Farmers Producer Co, TN (FPO); R K Tiwari, Asst Director, Dept. of Women and Child Development, Madhya Pradesh; Savitaben Vasava, millets farmer from Narmada, Gujarat. Senior policymakers, researchers, practitioners and agriculture experts participated in the event. Since 2010, Reliance Foundation has been focusing on sustainable agriculture and strengthening of food systems through a collaborative approach with various stakeholders. The work with millet small and marginal farmers is another step to build resilience in the face of changing climate while enhancing the nutritional status of communities. Having observed 2018 as its ‚ÄòNational Year of Millets‚Äô, India presented the proposal for the ‚ÄòInternational Year of Millets‚Äô (IYOM) in the United Nations. At the 75th General Assembly session of the UN in March 2021, the year 2023 was declared IYOM to increase global awareness of the benefits of consuming and growing millets. India is world‚Äôs largest millet producer and its average production of 16.93 million metric tons during 2019-22 was about 11% higher than the production during 2014-18. Though area under millet cultivation has reduced, productivity has markedly increased over the years. #reliancefoundation #millets

Reliance Industries Becomes First in India to Use Chemical Recycling for Circular Polymers The new innovation is a testimony to the company‚Äôs commitment in reducing plastic waste and supporting Circular Economy in India Reliance Industries Limited (RIL), operator of the world's largest integrated refining and petrochemical complex, has become the first Indian company to chemically recycle plastic waste-based pyrolysis oil into International Sustainability & Carbon Certification (ISCC)-Plus certified Circular Polymers. This new innovation is a testimony to RIL's commitment in reducing plastic waste and supporting Circular Economy in India. RIL shipped its first batch of ISCC-Plus certified Circular Polymers, named CircuRepol‚Ñ¢ (Polypropylene) and CircuRelene‚Ñ¢ (Polyethylene). RIL paves the way in India by using new technology to recycle plastic by converting plastic waste into special Circular Polymers, thereby making a positive impact on the environment. RIL‚Äôs commitment to sustainability is demonstrated through its innovative methods like chemical recycling which help create a Circular Economy. The company firmly believes in finding smart solutions to reduce plastic waste and inspire others to join in this journey towards a greener future. CircuRepol‚Ñ¢ and CircuRelene‚Ñ¢ have been designed to lead the way in Circular Economy practices. RIL's Jamnagar refinery became the first refinery to get the important ISCC-Plus certification, proving that it can produce Circular Polymers through chemical recycling. The ISCC-Plus certification guarantees that traceability and rules are followed in making Circular Polymers. RIL has developed a technology that turns different types of plastic waste, including single use and multi-layered plastics, into pyrolysis oil. The company is working with trusted partners to increase the production of this oil and turn the yield into Circular Polymers. Chemical recycling has many benefits, including turning plastic waste into high-quality materials for new plastic. These materials can be used for packaging that comes into contact with food. #WeCare #RelianceInnovation #CircularEconomy #SustainableFuture

message: Media Release - Jio Institute Successfully Hosted ViewPoint 2023 The landmark conclave in collaboration with HR Shapers explored growing AI integration in Human Resources Mumbai, 5th December 2023: Jio Institute successfully hosted ViewPoint 2023, an HR conclave that explored the intersection of AI and HR, highlighting how these technologies are reshaping recruitment, management, and workforce development. The second panel focused on ‚ÄúEmerging Trends in AI and Employment Opportunities‚Äù, featuring perspectives from Mr Amit Sawant (Associate Director ‚Äì Human Capital, PwC India), Mr Satej Mehta (General Manager ‚Äì HR, Wockhardt Ltd.), Ms Pradnya Sawant (CHRO, Vedanta Sesa Met Coke Division), and Ms Major Pratima Pinto Thomas (CHRO, Fino Payments Bank). Dr Raveendra Chittoor, Dean of Jio Institute, expressed enthusiasm, stating, ‚ÄúWe are thrilled to host ViewPoint 2023, a conclave that delves into the dynamic synergy between artificial intelligence and human resources. Jio Institute is proud to serve as a thought leadership platform, bringing new ideas and viewpoints to the table from industry and academia.‚Äù Key takeaways from the conclave emphasized the growing impact of AI on HR and the evolving landscape of employment opportunities in the AI era. The event provided a platform for HR professionals, academicians, industry leaders, and the students and staff of Jio Institute to network and exchange ideas. HR Shapers is committed to providing a space for industry leaders to connect, share insights, and navigate the ongoing transformative landscape of HR.‚Äù ViewPoint was attended by more than 50 HR professionals from various organisations such as Accenture, Ericsson India, Mastek, Gammon India, GO Airlines, Hindalco, Jio Platforms Ltd, Parle Agro, Reliance Retail, Samsung C&T, Strata Geosystems India, TAM Media, UBS, UPS, among others along with staff, students and alumni of Jio Institute. link_description: ‚ÄúThe soil is much softer and is able to retain water for long. Earthworms are bringing back life in the soil and the farm yield has increased. But now there is hope.‚Äù From struggling with deteriorating soil health to now infusing a new breathe of life in their farmlands, this is the story of Jayarani and her Farmer Producer's Company's successful journey of bringing their soil back to life. Jayarani belonged to the households in Keelakulam village, Ramanathapuram district, Tamil Nadu, that relied on paddy cultivation and cattle rearing as primary sources of livelihood. Due to commercialization, they were compelled to use costly and harmful chemical fertilizers, resulting in soil degradation. Jayarani says, ‚ÄúFarming paddy was not profitable. Many a times, after standing for hours in long queues to buy expensive fertilizers, I had to return empty handed due to high market demand.‚Äù Her life changed when she came across Reliance Foundation's work in empowering the women of Mugavai Farmer Producer Company to improve soil health for better harvests. She signed up for their training program to master the skill of vermicomposting, learning from experts of the Madurai Agri Business Incubation Forum (MABIF). Under the leadership, the 25 women who attended the session achieved a significant improvement in soil health, while also reducing their input costs by shifting to vermicompost and manure from chemical fertilizers. This #WorldSoilDay, Reliance Foundation is proud to celebrate the success and journeys of women farmers like Jayarani, who have strengthened the adoption of climate-resilient and better soil conservation practices, enabling countless farmers to harvest a brighter tomorrow. #RelianceFoundation #SustainableFarming #RelianceFoundationTransformingLives
